title: Theresa May's business rates 'climbdown' mired in confusion minutes after she announced it
text:

Labour hit out today after Theresa May's supposed climbdown on business rates was mired in confusion minutes after she announced it. 
After weeks of pressure, the Prime Minister revealed small firms losing out in a nationwide bills shake-up will get "appropriate relief". 
But speaking to journalists after today's announcement, Downing Street sources said there will not actually be any extra money. 
With the Budget just two weeks away, the source said: "We are mindful of the fact some companies are going to see their rates go up, that's why we're introducing this Â£3.6billion transitional fund to ease that transition for those firms that are affected. 
"I think the Prime Minister was just making sure that assistance is going to the right areas." 
A Labour source immediately hit back at the apparent chaos, saying: "It's clear there needs to be real transitional support. Read More PMQs recap: Theresa May dodges Jeremy Corbyn's NHS questions - but is forced into business rates climbdown 
"It's quite clear that there needs to be more support for small businesses facing these rates revaluations." 
Under-fire Tory Communities Secretary Sajid Javid will face MPs in the House of Commons later, where he will face calls to clarify exactly what the compromise is. The Prime Minister has been coming under heavy pressure over her rates shake-up Brighton Pier faces a rate rise of 17% (Photo: Getty) 
Tory MPs' anger had forced Theresa May into what first looked like a climbdown over her far-reaching shake-up of business rates. 
The campaign began when it emerged some web giants would be let off more lightly than small high-street shops. 
It is feared struggling firms will go to the wall when bills start arriving ahead of April. 
Green MP Caroline Lucas warned world-famous Brighton Pier is facing a 17% increase - while a nearby hotel faces a 400% hike. 
She said at Prime Minister's Questions today: "The government's business rates hike could devastate the local economy in my Brighton constituency." Mrs May faced anger over the business rates row at PMQs 
Mrs May replied: "Business rates, of course, are based on the rental values of properties. And the rental values of properties do change over time, they go up and down. 
"And it's right that rates change to recognise that. That's the principle of fairness that underpins the business rates system. 
"We also though want to support businesses, and recognise that for some, business rates will go up when these revaluations take place. 
"That's why we've put significant funding in place for transitional relief. 
"But I recognise there has been particular concern that there will be some small businesses that will be particularly adversely affected by the result of this revaluation. 
"That's why I've asked the Chancellor and the Communities Secretary to make sure there's appropriate relief in those hardest cases." Like us on Facebook
